picks.title: Bahia Palace
picks.subtitle: Best Architectural Experience
picks.whyWeLove: A breathtaking testament to Moroccan craftsmanship ‚Äî intricate zellige tile work, carved cedar ceilings, and tranquil courtyards create an atmosphere of timeless beauty. Don't miss the harem quarters with painted wooden ceilings.
tips: Visit early morning to avoid crowds

picks.title: Sunset at Jemaa el-Fna
picks.subtitle: Best Djemaa El Fna Experience
picks.whyWeLove: The world's greatest open-air show ‚Äî as the sun sets, the square transforms into a carnival of storytellers, musicians, snake charmers, henna artists, and the intoxicating aroma of grilled meats from dozens of food stalls.
tips: Arrive at 5pm for the best sunset spot
Caf√© de France rooftop for aerial views

picks.title: The Spice Souks
picks.subtitle: Best Shopping / Souks
picks.whyWeLove: Navigate mountains of saffron, cumin, and ras el hanout in the most photogenic market you'll ever visit. The sensory overload is the experience ‚Äî let yourself get wonderfully lost in the labyrinth.
tips: Walk away to get the best price
Visit Ensemble Artisanal first for fair price reference

picks.title: Nomad Restaurant
picks.subtitle: Best Dining Experience
picks.whyWeLove: Modern Moroccan cuisine elevated to an art form, served on a stunning rooftop terrace overlooking the medina. The lamb tagine with prunes and almonds is legendary, and their fresh juices are perfection.
tips: Try the camel burger at nearby Caf√© Clock too

picks.title: Traditional Riad Experience
picks.subtitle: Best Place to Stay
picks.whyWeLove: Sleeping in a riad is quintessential Marrakech ‚Äî zellige-tiled courtyards, plunge pools, rooftop terraces for breakfast, and intimate hospitality that makes you feel like a treasured guest.
tips: Book a riad in the Medina for authenticity
Riad Yasmine and El Fenn are standouts
Share your riad's GPS pin with taxi drivers

picks.title: Le Jardin Secret
picks.subtitle: Best Hidden Gem
picks.whyWeLove: Tucked away in the medina, this restored Islamic garden is a pocket of serenity ‚Äî geometric water channels, exotic plants, and a tower with some of the best panoramic views in the city. Most tourists walk right past it.
tips: Visit after lunch when it's quieter

picks.title: Caf√© des √âpices Terrace
picks.subtitle: Best Rooftop View
picks.whyWeLove: Perched above the spice market, this no-frills rooftop offers the most authentic panoramic view of the medina ‚Äî minarets, satellite dishes, and Atlas Mountain peaks on clear days. Perfect for a long, lazy juice break.
tips: Best views from the top terrace

picks.title: Mus√©e Yves Saint Laurent
picks.subtitle: Best Art & Design
picks.whyWeLove: A stunning terracotta building housing YSL's love letter to Marrakech ‚Äî rotating fashion exhibitions, a gorgeous garden, and a research library. The architecture alone is worth the visit.
tips: Caf√© in the garden is lovely

picks.title: Moroccan Cooking Class
picks.subtitle: Best Cultural Experience
picks.whyWeLove: Learn to prepare a proper tagine, couscous, and Moroccan salads from a local chef ‚Äî shopping for ingredients in the souk is part of the adventure. You'll eat better for the rest of your trip.
tips: Maison Arabe and Amal Center are top picks

picks.title: Maison de la Photographie
picks.subtitle: Best Museum Experience
picks.whyWeLove: A treasure trove of vintage Moroccan photography spanning 1870‚Äì1960. Intimate and uncrowded, with a wonderful rooftop caf√© serving mint tea with views over the medina rooftops.
tips: Rooftop caf√© is a hidden gem itself

picks.title: Gueliz & Hivernage
picks.subtitle: Best Experience in Gueliz
picks.whyWeLove: Marrakech's modern side ‚Äî tree-lined boulevards, concept stores, contemporary art galleries, and some of the city's best restaurants. A refreshing counterpoint to the medina's intensity.
tips: 33 Rue Majorelle for curated Moroccan design
Grand Caf√© de la Poste for colonial-era atmosphere
Walk Mohammed V avenue for boutiques

picks.title: Traditional Hammam Experience
picks.subtitle: Best Hammam Experience
picks.whyWeLove: Nothing says Morocco like a proper hammam scrub ‚Äî the ritual of black soap, eucalyptus steam, and vigorous kessa-glove exfoliation leaves you feeling reborn. An essential cultural experience.
tips: Heritage Spa and Hammam Mouassine are excellent
Go in the morning for a quieter visit

picks.title: Ben Youssef Medersa
picks.subtitle: Best Architectural Experience
picks.whyWeLove: Once the largest Islamic college in Morocco, this 14th-century masterpiece features stunning zellige tilework, carved stucco, and cedar wood carvings. The central courtyard with its reflecting pool is pure architectural poetry.
tips: Visit early morning for best photos
Combined ticket with nearby museums available

picks.title: Koutoubia Mosque
picks.subtitle: Best Architectural Experience
picks.whyWeLove: The iconic 12th-century minaret dominates Marrakech's skyline and inspired the Giralda in Seville. While non-Muslims can't enter, the surrounding gardens are perfect for a sunset stroll with views of the Atlas Mountains.

picks.title: Badi Palace
picks.subtitle: Best Architectural Experience
picks.whyWeLove: The atmospheric ruins of Sultan Ahmad al-Mansur's 16th-century palace, once called 'The Incomparable'. Storks nest in the crumbling walls, and the vast sunken gardens hint at past grandeur. The underground prison is hauntingly atmospheric.
tips: Visit late afternoon for golden light
Climb the walls for panoramic views
Watch for nesting storks in spring

picks.title: Almoravid Koubba
picks.subtitle: Best Architectural Experience
picks.whyWeLove: The only surviving structure from the Almoravid dynasty (12th century), this small ablutions pavilion is a treasure of early Moroccan architecture. The intricate carved dome and arches showcase the origins of Marrakech's architectural legacy.

picks.title: Saadian Tombs
picks.subtitle: Best Architectural Experience
picks.whyWeLove: Sealed for centuries and rediscovered in 1917, these ornate 16th-century royal tombs feature Italian Carrara marble, gilded honeycomb ceilings, and exquisite zellige. The Hall of Twelve Columns is breathtakingly beautiful.
tips: Visit at opening (9am) to avoid queues

picks.title: Bahia Palace
picks.subtitle: Best Architectural Experience
picks.whyWeLove: A breathtaking testament to Moroccan craftsmanship ‚Äî intricate zellige tile work, carved cedar ceilings, and tranquil courtyards create an atmosphere of timeless beauty. Don't miss the harem quarters with painted wooden ceilings.
tips: Visit early morning to avoid crowds

picks.title: Centre de la Femme Artisane
picks.subtitle: Best Shopping Experience
picks.whyWeLove: A women's cooperative showcasing authentic Moroccan handicrafts at fixed prices. Support local artisans directly while finding beautiful carpets, embroidery, leather goods, and textiles ‚Äî all made by skilled Moroccan women.

picks.title: Mustapha Blaoui
picks.subtitle: Best Shopping Experience
picks.whyWeLove: A legendary warehouse packed floor-to-ceiling with Moroccan treasures ‚Äî lanterns, furniture, ceramics, textiles, and antiques. Interior designers fly in from around the world to source here. Overwhelming in the best way.
tips: Allow at least an hour to explore

picks.title: Les Nomades de Marrakech
picks.subtitle: Best Shopping Experience
picks.whyWeLove: A beautifully curated boutique in the medina specializing in Berber carpets, vintage textiles, and nomadic tribal art. Each piece has a story, and the knowledgeable staff share the cultural heritage behind every item.
tips: Ask about carpet origins and meanings
High quality but prices reflect it

picks.title: Jardin Majorelle Boutique
picks.subtitle: Best Shopping Experience
picks.whyWeLove: The garden's boutique offers exquisite YSL-inspired designs, Majorelle blue ceramics, and curated Moroccan crafts. While pricier than the souks, the quality and design are impeccable ‚Äî perfect for special gifts.

picks.title: Naturom
picks.subtitle: Best Shopping Experience
picks.whyWeLove: Morocco's answer to organic beauty ‚Äî argan oil, black soap, ghassoul clay, and rose water straight from local cooperatives. Learn about traditional beauty rituals and take home authentic hammam products.
tips: Pure argan oil should smell nutty

picks.title: Rahba Kedima
picks.subtitle: Best Shopping Experience
picks.whyWeLove: The 'Old Square' is Marrakech's most atmospheric marketplace ‚Äî apothecary stalls selling spices, dried herbs, traditional remedies, and yes, chameleons. The surrounding carpet dealers and basket weavers add to the sensory overload.
